[[File:Liquefaction at Niigata.JPG|thumb|300px|[[Soil liquefaction]] during the [[1964 Niigata earthquake]]]] A '''geohazard''' is a geological state that may lead to widespread damage or risk.<ref>[http://www.geohazards.no International Centre for Geohazards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080302114513/http://www.geohazards.no/ |date=March 2, 2008 }}</ref> Geohazards are geological and environmental conditions and involve long-term or short-term geological processes. Geohazards can be relatively small features, but they can also attain huge dimensions (e.g., submarine or surface [[landslide]]) and affect local and regional socio-economy to a large extent (e.g., [[tsunami]]s).
==Geohazards== {{See also|Natural hazard}} Human activities, such as drilling through overpressured zones—could result in significant risk, and as such mitigation and prevention are paramount, through improved understanding of geohazards, their preconditions, causes and implications. In other cases, particularly in montane regions, natural processes can cause catalytic events of a complex nature, such as an [[avalanche]] hitting a lake causes a debris flow, with consequences potentially hundreds of miles away, or creating a [[lahar]] by volcanism.
The continued and multi-disciplinary investigation into the occurrence and implications of geohazards, in particular offshore geohazards in relation with the oil and gas exploration, lead to specific mitigation studies and establishing relevant prevention mechanisms.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Nadim | year = 2006 | title = Challenges to geo-scientists in risk assessment for sub-marine slides | url = | journal = Norwegian Journal of Geology | volume = 86 | issue = 3| pages = 351–362 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Solheim | first1 = A.| year = | title = , 2005. Ormen Lange – An integrated study for the safe development of a deep-water gas field within the Storegga Slide complex, NE Atlantic continental margin; executive summary | url = | journal = [[Marine and Petroleum Geology]] | volume = 22 | issue = 1–2| pages = 1–9 | doi=10.1016/j.marpetgeo.2004.10.001|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
* (Submarine) [[Landslide]]s * [[Debris flow]]s * Shallow [[gas]] accumulation * Overpressured zones (including gas and shallow water flows) * Naturally occurring [[Clathrate hydrate|gas hydrates]] and their climate-controlled meta-stability * Mud flows, diapirism and [[volcanism]]/[[volcano]]es * [[Flood basalt]] * [[Earthquake]]s and [[Seismology|seismicity]] * [[Tsunami]]s from [[tectonics]] and [[landslide]]s * [[Rockfall|Rock falls]] and [[landslide]]s
=== Geohazards in Earth's history === Eleven distinct [[flood basalt]] episodes occurred in the past 250 million years, resulting in [[large volcanic province]]s, creating [[plateau]]s and [[mountain range]]s on Earth.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/241/4866/663 http://pubs.giss.nasa.gov/docs/1988/1988_Rampino_Stothers_1.pdf|authors=[[Michael R. Rampino]] & Richard B. Stothers|title=Flood Basalt Volcanism During the Past 250 Million Years|doi=10.1126/science.241.4866.663|year=1988|journal=Science|volume=241|issue=4866|pages=663–668|pmid=17839077|bibcode = 1988Sci...241..663R }}</ref> Large igneous provinces have been connected to five [[mass extinction]] events. The timing of six out of eleven known provinces coincide with periods of [[global warming]] and marine [[Anoxic event|anoxia]]/dysoxia. Thus, suggesting that volcanic CO2 emissions can force an important effect on the [[climate system]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012825200000374|author=P.B. Wignall|title=Large igneous provinces and mass extinctions|doi=10.1016/S0012-8252(00)00037-4|year=2001|journal=Earth-Science Reviews|volume=53|issue=1-2|pages=1–33|bibcode=2001ESRv...53....1W}}</ref>
==Known geohazards== {{See also|Lists of earthquakes|List of largest volcanic eruptions}} * [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami]] *[[2008 Sichuan earthquake]] * [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]] * [[The Barrier]] (located in [[Garibaldi Provincial Park]]). <!--and others, to be added-->
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080302114513/http://www.geohazards.no/ International Centre for Geohazards (ICG)]

'''Global Running Day''' is a day that celebrates the sport of running. It is held annually on the first Wednesday of June.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://globalrunningday.org/|title=Global Running Day|website=globalrunningday.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-01}}</ref> Participants of all ages and abilities pledge to take part in some type of running activity by submitting their names through the Global Running Day website. Global Running Day 2018 is scheduled for June 6.
== History == Global Running Day was formerly known as National Running Day and began in the United States. The first event was in 2009.
The inaugural Global Running Day was held on June 1, 2016. More than 2.5 million people from 177 countries pledged to run more than 9.2 million miles.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nyrr.org/races-and-events/2016/global-running-day/as-its-happened|title=Global Running Day: As It Happened|work=NYRR|access-date=2017-03-01}}</ref> New York City Mayor, [[Bill de Blasio]], declared June 1, 2016 to be Global Running Day in the City of New York.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/nyrrnews/status/738086178289811457|title=NYRR Media Relations on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2017-03-01|language=en}}</ref> 2014 [[Boston Marathon]] winner [[Meb Keflezighi]] led a group run from the Boston Run Base,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://running.competitor.com/2016/06/news/a-run-in-boston-with-meb-keflezighi_151104|title=A Run in Boston With Meb Keflezighi {{!}} Competitor.com|date=2016-06-02|work=Competitor.com|access-date=2017-03-01|language=en-US}}</ref> and the Atlanta Track Club organized a “run around the clock” event, where at least one person from the Atlanta metro area would be running every hour of Global Running Day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.atlantatrackclub.org/blog/atlanta-track-club-to-run-around-the-clock-for-global-running-day|title=Atlanta Track Club to "Run around the Clock" for Global Running Day {{!}} Atlanta Track Club|website=www.atlantatrackclub.org|access-date=2017-03-01}}</ref>
== The Million Kid Run == The Million Kid Run is the youth division of Global Running Day and aims to have one million kids around the world participate in Global Running Day. Its focus is on making fitness fun, and inspiring kids to embrace running as a way to remain healthy and fit. In 2016, 672,030 youths took part.
== Global supporters == More than 100 organizations support Global Running Day and the Million Kid Run, including the [[World Marathon Majors|Abbott World Marathon Majors]], [[Atlanta Track Club]], [[Boston Athletic Association]], [[Competitor Group, Inc.|Competitor Group]], Houston Marathon Foundation, [[International Association of Athletics Federations]], Athletics for a Better World program, [[New York Road Runners]], Running USA, [[USA Track & Field]], and more<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nyrr.org/media-center/press-releases/2016-global-running-day-featuring-first-ever-million-kid-run-set-for-wednesday-june-1|title=2016 Global Running Day Featuring First-Ever Million Kid Run Set for Wednesday, June 1|work=NYRR|access-date=2017-03-01}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Other uses}} {{redirect|Bah humbug|the character who says this|Ebenezer Scrooge|other uses|}} {{wiktionary|humbug}} [[File:JENNY LIND HUMBUG.jpg|thumb|An 1850 cartoon of [[Jenny Lind]] outside [[P. T. Barnum]]'s New American Museum, New York City, 1850, captioned as a "Panorama of Humbug"]] [[File:Magic vs Science.jpg|thumb|''Humbugging, or raising the Devil'', 1800. [[Thomas Rowlandson|Rowlandson]]’s humbugging depicts the public as a credulous simpleton being distracted by a display of “the miraculous”, the better to have his pockets picked.]] A '''humbug''' is a person or object that behaves in a deceptive or dishonest way, often as a [[hoax]] or in jest.<ref name=Webster>{{cite web|title=Definition of Humbug|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/humbug|publisher=Merriam-Webster|accessdate=3 August 2012}}</ref><ref name=Collins>{{cite web|last=Collins|title=Definition of Humbug|url=http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/humbug|publisher=Collin's Dictionary|accessdate=3 August 2012}}</ref> The term was first described in 1751 as student [[slang]], and recorded in 1840 as a "nautical phrase".<ref>{{cite book | title=Two Years Before the Mast | author=Dana, Richard Henry Jr. | authorlink=Richard Henry Dana, Jr. | year=1840|quote=When there is danger or necessity, or when he is well used, no one can work faster than he; but the instant he feels that he is kept at work for nothing, or, as the nautical phrase is, 'humbugged,' no sloth could make less headway.}}</ref> It is now also often used as an exclamation to mean [[nonsense]] or [[gibberish]].
When referring to a person, a humbug means a [[fraud]] or [[impostor]], implying an element of unjustified publicity and spectacle. In modern usage, the word is most associated with the character [[Ebenezer Scrooge]], created by [[Charles Dickens]] in his novella ''[[A Christmas Carol]]''. His famous reference to [[Christmas]], '''"Bah! Humbug!"''', declaring Christmas to be a fraud, is commonly used in stage and television versions and also appeared frequently in the original book. The word is also prominently used in ''[[The Wonderful Wizard of Oz|The Wizard of Oz]]'', in which the Scarecrow refers to the Wizard as a humbug, and the Wizard agrees.
Another use of the word was by [[John Collins Warren]], a [[Harvard Medical School]] professor who worked at [[Massachusetts General Hospital]]. Dr. Warren performed the first public operation with the use of [[ether]] anesthesia, administered by [[William Thomas Green Morton]], a dentist. To the stunned audience at the Massachusetts General Hospital, Warren declared, "Gentlemen, this is no humbug."<ref>{{cite journal |last=Bennett |first=William |title=The Genealogy of Mass General |url=http://www.americanheritage.com/content/genealogy-mass-general?page=5 |journal=American Heritage Magazine |volume=35 |issue=6 |year=1984 |accessdate=2014-03-20}}</ref>
== Etymology ==
The oldest known written uses of the word are in the book ''The Student'' (1750–1751), ii. 41, where it is called "a word very much in vogue with the people of taste and fashion", and in Ferdinando Killigrew's ''The Universal Jester'', subtitled "a choice collection of many conceits ... bon-mots and humbugs" from 1754; as mentioned in ''Encyclopædia Britannica'' from 1911, which further refers to the ''New English Dictionary''.<ref name=EB1911>{{cite EB1911 |wstitle=Humbug |volume=13 |page=876}}</ref>
There are many theories as to the origin of the term, none of which has been proven: * [[Charles Godfrey Leland]] mentions the idea that the word could be derived from the [[Old Norse|Norse]] word ''hum'', meaning 'night' or 'shadow', and the word ''bugges'' (used in the Bible), a variant of ''bogey'', meaning 'apparitions'.<ref>[[Charles Godfrey Leland]], ''Gypsy Sorcery and Fortune Telling'' [1891], Chapter X [http://www.sacred-texts.com/pag/gsft/gsft12.htm of ''The Haunts, Homes, and Habits of Witches in The South Slavic Lands--Bogeys and Humbugs'']</ref> The Norse word ''hum'' mentioned, or ''hume'', actually means 'dark air' in [[Old Norwegian]]. From the other [[North Germanic languages|Scandinavian languages]] based on Old Norse, there is ''húm'' in [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]] which means 'twilight', ''hómi'' in [[Faeroese language|Faeroese]] which means 'unclear', and ''humi'' in Old [[Swedish language|Swedish]] which means 'dark suspicion', documented back to 1541.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saob.se/artikel/?seek=hum|title=Svenska Akademiens ordbok s.v. Hum|last=|first=|date=|website=www.saob.se|publisher=|accessdate=2016-11-29}}</ref> From this word is also derived the Swedish verb ''hymla'', still in use, which means 'to conceal, hide, not commit to the truth'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saob.se/artikel/?seek=hymla|title='Svenska Akademiens ordbok s.v. Hymla|last=|first=|date=|website=www.saob.se|publisher=|accessdate=2016-11-29}}</ref> * According to the ''Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue'' by [[Francis Grose]], 1731–1791, ''to hum'' in English indeed originally meant 'to deceive'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext04/dcvgr10.txt |title=Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue |date= |accessdate=2011-12-10}}</ref> To combine this early medieval Scandinavian word with ''bugges'' from the English Bible of a later date may seem far-fetched. The word ''bug'' is derived from the [[Middle English]] ''Bugge'' (of which the term ''[[Bogeyman|bogey]]'' is also derived) which is in turn a cognate of the German word ''bögge'' (of which ''böggel-mann'' (''"Goblin"'') is derived)<ref name=etym/><ref>''Middle English Dictionary'' by Sherman M. Kuhn, Hans Kurath, Robert E. Lewis, University of Michigan Press, 1958, {{ISBN|978-0-472-01025-7}}, page 1212</ref><ref>''Merriam-Webster's collegiate dictionary'', 11th edition, Merriam-Webster, 2003, {{ISBN|978-0-87779-809-5}}, page 162</ref> and possibly the Norwegian dialect word ''bugge'' meaning "important man".<ref name=merriamwebster>''The Merriam-Webster new book of word histories'', Merriam-Webster, 1991, {{ISBN|978-0-87779-603-9}}, page 71</ref> The Welsh ''bwg'' (''"ghost"'') could also be connected,<ref name=etym>{{cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=bug |title=Online Etymology Dictionary |publisher=Etymonline.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-10}}</ref> and was thought in the past to be the origin of the English term however more recent studies indicate that it is a borrowing from the much older Middle English word.<ref>''Metatony in Baltic, Volume 6 of Leiden studies in Indo-European'' by Rick Derksen, Rodopi, 1996, {{ISBN|90-5183-990-1}}, {{ISBN|978-90-5183-990-6}}, page 274</ref><ref>''Lexical reflections inspired by Slavonic *bog : English bogey from a Slavonic root?'', Brian Cooper 1, Department of Slavonic Studies, University of Cambridge, Correspondence to Department of Slavonic Studies, University of Cambridge, Sidgwick Avenue, Cambridge CB3 9DA</ref><ref>''Early Modern Northern English Lexis: A Literary Corpus-Based Study'', Javier Ruano-Garcia, Peter Lang, 2010, {{ISBN|3-0343-0058-1}}, {{ISBN|978-3-0343-0058-2}}. pp. 242–243</ref><ref>''Studies in folk life'', John Geraint Jenkins, Iorwerth Cyfeiliog Peate, Ayer Publishing, 1977,{{ISBN|0-405-10102-3}}, {{ISBN|978-0-405-10102-1}}. p. 304</ref> Also, with ''bug'' meaning ghost or goblin, the use of the term applies in Dickens' novel about the Christmas ghosts. In ''Etym. Diet.'' of 1898, [[Walter Skeat]] also proposed a similar theory, although using contemporary versions of the words, where ''hum'' meant to murmur applause, and ''bug'' being a spectre.<ref name=EB1911/> * It could also come from the [[Italian language|Italian]] ''uomo bugiardo'', which literally means 'lying man'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.factmonster.com/dictionary/brewers/humbug.html |title=Factmonster |publisher=Factmonster |date= |accessdate=2011-12-10}}</ref> There was considerable Italian influence on English at the time (e.g. Shakespeare's numerous Italian-based plays, approximately 150 years before the first recorded use of 'humbug'). * ''Uim-bog'' is supposed to mean 'soft copper' in [[Irish language|Irish]], worthless money, but there is no evidence of a clear connection to the term.<ref name=EB1911/> * The 1911 ''Encyclopædia Britannica'' also suggests that it is a form of "[[Hamburg]]",<ref name=EB1911/> where false coins were minted and shipped to England during the Napoleonic wars, which is inaccurate as the Napoleonic wars occurred 50 years after the word first appeared in print. * A modern conception is that it actually refers to a humming bug—''i.e.'' something small and inconsequential, such as a [[Cricket (insect)|cricket]], that makes a lot of noise.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.word-detective.com/012504.html#humbug |title=word-detective |publisher=word-detective |date=2004-01-25 |accessdate=2011-12-10}}</ref> In [[Norton Juster]]'s novel ''[[The Phantom Tollbooth]]'', there is a large beetle-like insect known as the Humbug, who is hardly ever right about anything.
The word has been used outside of anglophone countries for well over a century. For instance, in Germany it has been known since the 1830s,<ref>{{cite web|author=Horst Conrad |url=http://www.etymologie.info/~e/u_/us-ismen_.html |title=etymologie.info |publisher=Etymologie.info |date= |accessdate=2011-12-10}}</ref> in Sweden since at least 1862,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saob.se/artikel/?seek=humbug|title=Svenska Akademiens ordbok s.v. Humbug|last=|first=|date=|website=www.saob.se|publisher=|accessdate=2016-11-29}}</ref> in France since at least 1875,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.littre.org/definition/humbug |title=Dictionnaire de la Langue Francaise, Littré 1872-1877 |publisher=www.littre.org |date= |accessdate=2013-07-22}}</ref> in Hungary, and in Finland.

<!-- notability|Biographies|date=August 2014 --> {{Infobox person |name = Jennifer Gilbert |image = File:Jennifer Gilbert.jpg |birth_date = {{birth_date and age|1968|12|24}} |birth_place = |death_place = |occupation = Entrepreneur, TV personality |alma_mater = [[University of Vermont]] |known_for = Founder of ''Save the Date'' |citizenship = United States |networth = |residence = [[New York City|Greater New York City]] |salary = |spouse = |children = }}
'''Jennifer Gilbert''' (born December 24, 1968) is an American [[entrepreneur]] and [[TV personality]]. She is the founder and chief visionary officer of ''Save the Date'', a [[New York City|New York]]–based special events company. She was named one of the ''entrepreneurs of the year'' by [[Ernst & Young]] for her event planning company, ''Save the Date'' in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|title=Enchanted Evenings: New York's Top Event Planners|author=Polster, Allison|url=https://gotham-magazine.com/new-yorks-top-event-planners|website=[[Gotham (magazine)|gotham-magazine.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> She has also appeared on the TV series ''[[Real Housewives of New York City]]''.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ernst, Amanda|title=Jennifer Gilbert Reacts To Her Hilarious ‘Real Housewives’ Debut|url=http://www.crushable.com/2010/05/07/entertainment/exclusive-jennifer-gilbert-reacts-to-her-hilarious-real-housewives-debut/|date=May 7, 2010|website=crushable.com|publisher=[[Defy Media]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref name="ref1">{{cite news|author=Palmer, Amy|title=When a 20-Year-Old Secret is Revealed: 'I Refuse to Be A Victim'|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/amy-palmer/jennifer-gilbert_b_1519270.html|date=May 7, 2010|work=[[HuffPost]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Cruz, Clarissa|author2=Bailly, Jenny|url=http://www.oprah.com/style/female-authors-model-summer-fashion-under-100|title=7 Authors Model Summer's Most Sizzling (Under-$100!) Outfits|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
==Early life and career== Gilbert graduated from the [[University of Vermont]] in 1990 and received a [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[Consumer market|Consumer Marketing]] with a minor in Business. After graduation Gilbert moved to [[New York City]]. In 1991, at the age of 22, a stranger attacked her, stabbing her 37 times with a screwdriver before leaving her for dead.<ref name="ref1"/><ref>{{cite web|title=The Scars You Don't See|url=http://www.marieclaire.com/world-reports/jennifer-gilbert-attack|website=[[Marie Claire|marieclaire.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jennifer-gilbert/finally-an-anniversary-to_b_10228850.html|title=Finally, an Anniversary to Celebrate|author=Gilbert, Jennifer|date=June 2, 2016|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Abbasi, Jennifer|url=https://www.success.com/article/jennifer-gilbert-woman-warrior|title=Jennifer Gilbert: Woman Warrior|date=April 11, 2014|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
After recovering, she decided to become an [[Event planning|event planner]] and started ''Save the Date'', a New York based [[event planning]] company, in 1994.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inc.com/magazine/201207/burt-helm/jennifer-gilbert-save-the-date-how-i-did-it.html|title='Why I Will Never Be a Victim'|date=June 28, 2012|magazine=[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=How I Rebuilt My Life After Being Attacked|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/jennifer-gilbert/how-i-rebuilt-my-life-after-attack_b_1581340.html|author=Gilbert, Jennifer|date=August 6, 2012|work=HuffPost|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> In 2010 she sued a dating company with similar name called Save the Dating, the company went off business after lawsuit.<ref>{{cite news|author=Cowles, Charlotte|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2010/04/new_housewife_jennifer_gilbert.html|title=New Housewife Jennifer Gilbert Sues New York Matchmaking Business; Gerunds Involved|work=[[New York Post]]|date=April 9, 2010|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> The company has rendered services to many notable companies including several in [[Fortune 500]] companies and has been retained by clients such as [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]], [[Oprah Winfrey]] and singer [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Jennifer Gilbert - Who is She|url=http://www.ladieswholaunch.com/magazine/jennifer-gilbert/1094|publisher=ladieswholaunch.com|date=May 11, 2004|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/video/277455|title=Jennifer Gilbert Bounced Back From a Near-Fatal Attack to Find Massive Business Success|author=Schultz, Erin|website=Entrepreneur|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
She is also the co-owner of Portamee, a [[baby carrier]] company.<ref>{{cite web|title=Portamee - who are WEe|url=http://www.portamee.com/who.html|publisher=portamee.com|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> She has also authored a book, ''I Never Promised You A Goodie Bag'', in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=I Never Promised You a Goodie Bag: A Memoir of a Life Through Events--the Ones You Plan and the Ones You Don't|url=https://www.amazon.com/Never-Promised-You-Goodie-Events/dp/B00B558OSO|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Jennifer Gilbert, Author Of Memoir 'I Never Promised You A Goodie Bag,' Talks Success After Violence|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/14/jennifer-gilbert-i-never-promised-you-a-goodie-bag_n_1516243.html|work=HuffPost|accessdate=April 26, 2018|date=May 14, 2012}}</ref> In her book, she discussed about how her life changed after being attacked at a young age and then how she got control on her life and started a successful company.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jennifer Gilbert|url=http://www.myfoxny.com/story/18441551/jennifer-gilbert|date=May 17, 2012|publisher=myfoxny.com|accessdate=May 19, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819012819/http://www.myfoxny.com/story/18441551/jennifer-gilbert |archivedate=August 19, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> She spoke at [[TEDx]] [[Barnard College|Barnard College Women]] sharing her entrepreneurial spirit and philosophy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Entrepreneurial Spirit: Jennifer Gilbert at TEDxBarnardCollegeWomen|url=http://socksonanoctopus.com/ted-talks-entrepreneurial-spirit-jennifer-gilbert/|publisher=Soccks on an Octopus|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
==TV appearances== She appeared as herself in the [[Bravo (U.S. TV channel)|Bravo's]] hit TV series ''[[Real Housewives of New York City]]'' in 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=New 'Housewife' Jennifer Gilbert Loses Airtime, Cut From Reunion Special|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/03/new-housewife-jennifer-gi_0_n_598857.html|author=Rancilio, Alicia|agency=[[Associated Press|AP]]|date=February 6, 2010|work=[[HuffPost]]|accessdate=May 19, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129085209/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/03/new-housewife-jennifer-gi_0_n_598857.html|archivedate=November 29, 2014|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> She was the party planner for [[Jill Zarin]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet NYC’s new ‘Real Housewives’ set to shake up the show|url=https://nypost.com/2010/04/01/meet-nycs-new-real-housewives-set-to-shake-up-the-show/|date=April 1, 2010|publisher=[[nypost.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018|author=Eber, Hailey}}</ref>
==Personal life== In 1994, Gilbert met her husband, a [[Wall Street]] Executive, Bennett Egeth and the two were married in [[New York City]] 7 years later.
Gilbert lives in [[New York City]] with her husband, their daughter and twin boys.<ref>{{cite news|title=WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS: VOWS; Jennifer Gilbert and Bennett Egeth|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/01/style/weddings-celebrations-vows-jennifer-gilbert-and-bennett-egeth.html|date=December 1, 2002|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018|author=Louie, Elaine}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Jessica McClure | image = | birth_name = Jessica McClure | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|3|26}} | birth_place = [[Midland, Texas]], U.S. | known_for = falling into a well at 18 months | other_names = Jessica McClure Morales | spouse = {{marriage|Daniel Morales|2006}} | children = 2 }} '''Jessica McClure Morales''' (born March 26, 1986) became famous on October 14, 1987, at the age of 18 months after she fell into a [[water well|well]] in her aunt's backyard in [[Midland, Texas]]. Between that day and October 16, rescuers worked for 56 hours to free her from the {{convert|8|in|cm|adj=on|spell=in}} [[casing (borehole)|well casing]] {{convert|22|ft|m}} below the ground.{{cite web|url=http://abc13.com/30-years-ago-rescue-of-baby-jessica-from-the-well/1555516/|title=30 years ago: Rescue of 'Baby Jessica' from the well|date=October 14, 2016|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/18-month-old-girl-saved-1987-article-1.2386153|title=Jessica McClure, an 18-month-old girl, is saved after 58 long hours trapped in a well in 1987 - NY Daily News|publisher=}} The story gained worldwide attention (leading to some criticism as a [[media circus]]), and later became the subject of a 1989 [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] television movie ''[[Everybody's Baby: The Rescue of Jessica McClure]]''. == Rescue == McClure's rescue proved to be a much more difficult ordeal than was first anticipated. Within hours of beginning the emergency procedure, the Midland Fire and Police Departments devised a plan that involved drilling another shaft parallel to the well and then drilling a tunnel at a right angle across to it. Enlisting the help of a variety of local (often out-of-work) oil-drillers, the Midland officials had hoped to free McClure in minutes. However, the first workers to arrive on the scene found their tools barely adequate to penetrate the hard rock around the well. It took about six hours to drill the shaft and longer to drill the tunnel, because the [[jackhammer]]s used were designed for drilling downward, rather than sideways. A mining engineer eventually arrived to help supervise and coordinate the rescue effort. TV viewers watched as paramedics and rescuers, drilling experts and contractors worked tirelessly to save the baby's life. Meanwhile, they were reassured when they heard Jessica singing “[[Winnie the Pooh (song)|Winnie the Pooh]]” from deep in the well. As long as she was still singing, they knew she was still alive.{{cite news|last1=Higgins|first1=Darla|title=Baby Jessica 30 Years Later: 'My Life Is a Miracle'|url=http://people.com/human-interest/baby-jessica-30-years-later-my-life-is-a-miracle/|accessdate=15 October 2017|website=People.com|date=31 May 2017|quote=Television viewers watched as hundreds of paramedics, rescuers, drilling experts and contractors feverishly worked to save the baby's life. Meanwhile, they were reassured when they heard Jessica singing “[[Winnie the Pooh (song)|Winnie the Pooh]]” from deep in the well. As long as she was singing, she was still alive.}} Forty-five hours after McClure fell into the well, the shaft and tunnel were finally completed. The relatively new technology of [[Water jet cutter|waterjet cutting]], used to cut through the hard rock surrounding the well, was a vital part of the rescue.{{cite book|title=Business Week|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p-0dAQAAMAAJ|year=1989|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.}}{{cite book|author=National Science Foundation (U.S.)|title=Annual report for fiscal year ...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7EEc-gZcTJkC|year=1987|publisher=The Foundation}} Ron Short, a muscular roofing contractor who was born without collar bones because of [[cleidocranial dysostosis]] and so could collapse his shoulders to work in cramped corners, arrived at the site and offered to go down the shaft. They considered his offer, but did not use it.{{cite news |first= J. Michael |last= Kennedy |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-10-17/news/mn-3702_1_jessica-mcclure |title=Jessica Makes It to Safety—After 58 1/2 Hours |work= [[Los Angeles Times]] |date=October 17, 1987 |accessdate=November 24, 2010}}{{cite journal|first=Ronald W. |last=Scott |url=http://www.jospt.org/members/getfile.asp?id=3740 |format=PDF |title=Cleidocranial Dysplasia: An Enigma Among Anomalies |journal=The Journal of Orthopaedic and Sports Physical Therapy |date=November 1988 |volume=10 |issue=5 |pages=184–8 |issn=0190-6011 |accessdate=November 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404192505/http://www.jospt.org/members/getfile.asp?id=3740 |archivedate=April 4, 2012 |df= }} One report said that he helped to clear tunneling debris away.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcuniversalarchives.com/nbcuni/clip/5112434055_s02.do|title=Home - News, Entertainment, World Events Video - NBCUniversal Archives|website=NBCUniversal Archives|accessdate=May 26, 2018}} Midland Fire Department paramedic Robert O'Donnell was ultimately able to inch his way into the tunnel and wrestle McClure free from the confines of the well, handing her to fellow paramedic Steve Forbes, who carried her up to safety. == Media coverage == [[CNN]] was on the scene with around-the-clock coverage of the rescue effort. This massive media saturation of the ordeal prompted then-President [[Ronald Reagan]] to state that "everybody in America became godmothers and godfathers of Jessica while this was going on." From the beginning and throughout the incident, the switchboard of local media outlet [[KMID-TV]] was flooded with telephone calls from news organizations and private individuals around the world, seeking the latest information on rescue efforts. In some cases, they shared their own insight into this and similar incidents. In 1988, McClure and her parents appeared on ''[[Live with Regis and Kathie Lee]]'' to talk about the incident. The photograph of McClure being rescued fetched the [[1988 Pulitzer Prize|1988]] [[Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Photography|Pulitzer Prize for Spot News Photography]] to Scott Shaw of the ''[[Odessa American]]''.{{cite web |author= Staff |url=http://www.pulitzer.org/awards/1988 |title= 1988 Winners and Finalists |work= The Pulitzer Prizes |publisher= Columbia University |date= |accessdate=November 24, 2010}} ABC made a television movie of the story in 1989, ''[[Everybody's Baby: The Rescue of Jessica McClure]]'', starring [[Patty Duke]] and [[Beau Bridges]]. It featured many participants in the actual rescue and its coverage as extras. On May 30, 2007, ''[[USA Today]]'' ranked McClure number 22 on its list of "25 lives of indelible impact."{{cite web|last=Koch |first=Wendy |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/top25-people.htm |title=Lives of Indelible Impact |work= [[USA Today]] |date=May 29, 2007 |accessdate=November 24, 2010}} == Aftermath == [[File:President George H.W. Bush holds Jessica McClure in the Roosevelt Room at the White House (1989-07-19).jpg|thumb|President [[George H. W. Bush]] meeting McClure at the White House in 1989]] Following McClure's rescue on October 16, 1987, surgeons had to amputate a toe due to [[gangrene]] from loss of circulation while she was in the well. She also has a scar on her forehead where her head rubbed against the well casing. She had 15 surgeries over the years and has no first-hand memory of the event.{{cite web |url= http://www9.comcast.net/articles/news-national/20110325/US.Baby.Jessica/ |last= Blaney |first= Betsy |title= Baby Jessica turns 25, gains access to trust fund |work= Xfinity News |agency= [[Associated Press]] |date= March 25, 2011 |accessdate= March 25, 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110326215656/http://www.comcast.net/articles/news-national/20110325/US.Baby.Jessica/ |archivedate= March 26, 2011}} Her parents divorced a few years after the rescue. Paramedic Robert O'Donnell, battling [[posttraumatic stress disorder]] as a result of the arduous rescue effort and struggling to cope with the abrupt decline of the fame and recognition that had been lavished on him following his heroic act, committed suicide in 1995.{{cite news |last1=Belkin|first1=Lisa |title=Death on the CNN Curve |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/23/magazine/death-on-the-cnn-curve.html |accessdate=July 18, 2017 |work=The New York Times |date=July 23, 1995}} McClure graduated from [[Greenwood Independent School District|Greenwood High School]], in a small community near Midland, in May 2004. On January 28, 2006, nineteen-year-old McClure married Daniel Morales at [[Church of Christ]] in [[Notrees, Texas]], about 40 miles from Midland. They met at a day care center where she worked with his sister.{{cite news |last= Celizic |first= Mike |url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/19165433/ |title= Baby Jessica 20 Years Later |publisher= [[MSNBC]] |date= November 6, 2007 |accessdate= November 24, 2010}} They have two children, a boy born 2007 and a girl born 2009.{{cite news|url=https://people.com/human-interest/baby-jessica-on-the-30-year-anniversary-of-her-rescue-from-a-well-her-life-as-a-wife-and-mom/|title=Baby Jessica On the 30 Year Anniversary of Her Rescue from a Well: Her Life as a Wife and Mom|first=Steve|last=Helling|date=October 16, 2017|publisher=[[People magazine]]}} When McClure turned 25 on March 26, 2011, she received a [[escrow|trust fund]] of donations worth up to $800,000. Her father said she had discussed setting up a trust fund for the college education of her children. It had earlier helped in the purchase of her present home, which is less than {{convert|2|mi|km|spell=in}} from the site of the incident. == In popular culture == * Footage of McClure's rescue appeared in [[Michael Jackson]]'s music video for the song "[[Man in the Mirror]]".{{YouTube|PivWY9wn5ps|Michael Jackson - Man In The Mirror (Official Video); 3:45}} * [[Lucie Brock-Broido]]'s long narrative poem "Jessica from the Well" (1988) tells the story from McClure's point of view, describing her as having a basic understanding of the physical and mythic elements of her situation. It has been reprinted numerous times.{{cite book |first= Lucie |last= Brock-Broido |chapter= Jessica, from the Well |title= A Hunger |location= New York |publisher=Knopf |year= 1988 |isbn= 978-0-394-56337-4 }} * A 1990 Indian movie, ''[[Malootty]]'', was based on the incident.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} *''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode "[[Radio Bart]]" (1992) revolved around a similar incident.http://www.popmatters.com/column/119350- the-simpsons-radio-bart-9-january-1992-part-2/{{cite web|url=http://www.gabbinggeek.com/2016/03/30/simpsons-did-it-radio-bart/|title=Simpsons Did It!: "Radio Bart"|date=March 30, 2016|website=Gabbinggeek.com|accessdate=May 26, 2018}} * In the 1995 film ''[[12 Monkeys]]'', a heavily fictionalized version of the Jessica McClure story plays out in TV and radio newscasts throughout the film. The entire nation is transfixed as a nine-year-old boy named "Ricky Newman" is believed to have fallen down a well in Fresno, California. Rescuers similarly dig a second well parallel to the one they think he is in, but James Cole (Bruce Willis) tells Kathryn Railly (Madeleine Stowe) that the boy is, in fact, hiding in a barn. He is later proven right. He knows this because he is a time traveler and remembers the events from when he was a child. * In 2010, [[blues]] musician [[Charlie Musselwhite]] released an album titled ''The Well''. In the title song he credits McClure's ordeal for inspiring him to quit drinking.{{cite news |url= http://leisureblogs.chicagotribune.com/turn_it_up/2010/09/how-baby-jessica-saved-blues-great-charlie-musselwhite.html |title= How 'Baby Jessica' Saved Blues Great Charlie Musselwhite |first= Greg |last= Kot |work= [[Chicago Tribune]] |date= September 28, 2010 |accessdate= June 4, 2013}} * A 2012 episode of ''[[American Dad!]]'' titled "[[National Treasure 4: Baby Franny: She's Doing Well: The Hole Story]]" featured a storyline which was essentially a parody of McClure's story, including a story revolving around the misfortunes of her rescuer.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} *In a ''[[Modern Family]]'' episode "Heavy is the Head" (2017) Cam reveals he fell into a well the same day as McClure, but she got all the press.{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/tv/cams-bitter-rivalry-with-baby-jessica-on-modern-family-070139822.html|title=Cam's Bitter Rivalry With Baby Jessica on 'Modern Family'|website=Yahho.com|accessdate=May 26, 2018}} == See also == * [[Floyd Collins]], an early case of "man trapped in cave" that received similar coverage in 1925 * [[2010 Copiapó mining accident]], a similarly highly covered event * [[Kathy Fiscus]], a child who died after falling into a well in 1949 * [[Alfredo Rampi]], a child who died after falling into a well in 1981 * [[Tikki Tikki Tembo]] * ''[[The Well (1951 film)|The Well]]'', 1951 film in which a little girl falls into a well and the town unites to save her by drilling a parallel shaft == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb name|id=1532391|name=Jessica McClure}} *"[http://www.vqronline.org/articles/1988/summer/brockbroido-jessica-from-well/ Jessica, from the Well]" poem by Lucie Brock-Broido {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McClure, Jessica}} [[Category:1986 births]] [[Category:1987 in Texas]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Accidents]] [[Category:People from Midland, Texas]]

'''Katie Martin''' (born '''Katie Louise Van Veen''' on January 8, 1972) is an American [[consultant]] in [[Environmentally friendly|eco-friendly]] special events, [[floral design]], and green events and life styles.
== Personal life == {{unreferenced|date=July 2018|section}} Martin was born in [[Washington, DC]]. She graduated from the [[University of Maryland, College Park]], in 1994 with a BS in [[accounting]]. She has one son and is married to Neftali Miguel Vasquez Perez.
== Features and interviews == * [[Style Network]]'s show ''[[Whose Wedding Is It Anyway]]?''<ref>[http://video.tvguide.com/ID/544864 ''TV Guide.'' Whose Wedding Is It Anyway?]</ref> * [[Washingtonian magazine|''Washingtonian'' magazine]]<ref>[http://www.washingtonian.com/chats/shopping/10456.html Washingtonian.com: Wedding Planner Chat with Katie Martin]</ref> * ''[[Washington Post]]''<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/06/22/AR2005062201475.html ''Washington Post''. "Down the Aisle, Into the Melting Pot."]</ref> *''Elegant Bride'' magazine<ref>[http://www.brides.com/planning/flowers/feature/article/6399#top Brides.com. Expert design.]</ref> *''Floral Management'' magazine<ref>[http://www.eleganceandsimplicity.com/press.htm ''Floral Management''. "The Chosen One." (Select #48)]</ref> *[[WUSA (TV)|WUSA]] (Washington, DC, CBS affiliate)<ref>[http://www.wusa9.com/news/news_article.aspx?storyid=33016 WUSA. Local Couple Prepares for 9/11 Wedding.]</ref> *[[WTOP-FM|WTOP]] (Washington, DC, talk-radio station)<ref>[http://www.eleganceandsimplicity.com/images/press/09-10%20a%20720%20Sept%2011th%20Wedding.mp3 WTOP]</ref> *[[TBD TV]] (Washington, DC, cable television network)<ref>http://www.letstalklive.tv/n_videoplayer.cfm?video=ltlmartin0129.wmv&id=105</ref>
Martin’s work also has been showcased in ''DC Modern Luxury Magazine'', ''Flower Magazine'', ''Catering Magazine'', ''Florists' Review'', ''Washington Woman'', ''Grace Ormonde'', ''Upscale Magazine'', ''Bride & Bloom'', ''Modern Bride'', ''My Day Magazine'', ''The Knot'', ''Engaged Magazine'', and ''La Bella Bride''.
Founded in 1998, Martin's wedding and event planning company, Elegance & Simplicity Wedding & Event Designers, Inc. (located in [[Bethesda, Maryland]] with a sister office in [[Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic]]) has planned about 3,500 [[wedding]]s worldwide.<ref name="washingtonian.com">[http://www.washingtonian.com/blogarticles/weddings/bridalparty/10469.html Washingtonian.com. Bridal Party Chat: Ask an Ecofriendly Planner]</ref> Martin also founded and runs Green Life DC, a consulting firm that helps individuals, families, events and businesses be more environmentally friendly.
Currently Martin is writing a book on [[green wedding]]s.<ref name="washingtonian.com"/>

{{Unreferenced|date=August 2017}} A '''latent human error''' is a [[human error]] which is likely to be made due to systems or routines that are formed in such a way that humans are disposed to making these errors. Latent human error is a term used in safety work and accident prevention, especially in [[aviation]].
By gathering data about errors made, then collating, grouping and analyzing them, it can be determined whether a disproportionate amount of similar errors are being made. If this is the case, a contributing factor may be disharmony between the respective systems/routines and human nature or [[Propensity probability|propensities]]. The routines or systems can then be analyzed, potential problems identified, and amendments made if necessary, in order to prevent future errors, incidents or accidents.

[[File:Lets Do It Mediterranean action in Cyprus.jpg|thumb|Let's Do It! Mediterranean 2014 action in Cyprus]] [[File:Let's Do It! Afghanistan.jpg|thumb|Let's Do It! Afghanistan 2015]] '''Let's Do It! World''' is a global civic movement that started from [[Estonia]], asking people worldwide to join a series of local, national and regional clean-up events. Among other projects, it is the founder of '''[[World Cleanup Day]]'''.
The Let's Do It! movement was first conceived in Estonia in year 2008, where a country clean-up action called '''[[Let's Do It 2008|Let's do it!]]''' (in [[Estonian language|Estonian]]: "Teeme Ära!") cleaned up 10,000 tons of illegal waste by more than 50,000 volunteers in one day. Following Estonia's lead many countries also started their own country clean-up events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinkitimes.fi/htimes/domestic-news/general/15176-finland-gets-spring-cleaning.html |title=Finland gets spring cleaning |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://blog.heifer.org/2011/07/ukrainian-participants-clean-up-their.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120715071118/http://blog.heifer.org/2011/07/ukrainian-participants-clean-up-their.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-15 |title=Ukrainian Participants Clean Up Their Village |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02 }}</ref> In 2011 a new initiative called Let's do it! World was started with the aim of promoting massive clean-ups from 24 March 2012 till 15 September 2012.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/cyberguided-cleanup-hopes-to-sweep-globe-2281350.html |title=Cyber-guided clean-up hopes to sweep globe |date= 2011-05-09|accessdate=2012-01-02 |location=London |work=The Independent}}</ref> After a successful World Cleanup 2012 project the next bigger goal is to have [[World Cleanup Day]] in 2018.
Today, the movement has grown into a network of 113 countries. All together, 14 million participants have been engaged in movement's activities.<ref>Kalev Leetaru: [https://www.forbes.com/sites/kalevleetaru/2016/07/30/how-pokemon-and-location-based-augmented-reality-could-save-the-planet/#4f804c9766cc "How Pokémon And Location-Based Augmented Reality Could Save The Planet"] Forbes, 2016-07-30</ref>
Let's Do It! World is an accredited member of the [[United Nations Environment Programme|United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP)]].
Since 2017, the movement uses [[W sign]] aka Three Fingers Up as a symbol.
{{TOC limit|limit=3}}
==The origins of the massive cleanup movement== On the 3rd of May 2008 over 50,000 people came out of their homes to clean up Estonia, the rest followed the process via all the media channels. That's 4% out of a population of 1,3 million - which would equal 15,3 million in the USA or 57 million in India. The idea spread from Estonia to the whole Europe and beyond.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20100125-anti-garbage-campaigners-plan-mass-internet-led-clean |title=Anti-garbage campaigners plan mass Internet-led clean up |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100129054219/http://www.france24.com/en/20100125-anti-garbage-campaigners-plan-mass-internet-led-clean |archivedate=2010-01-29 |df= }}</ref> Next spring, in 2009, Latvia and Lithuania cleaned their countries with more than 250,000 people participating and have done it henceforth for three years, engaging more people each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hCNrezFwQUYGj2rJNJJ75ENwcDgQ |title=AFP: Massive clean-up drive in Latvia, Lithuania |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref> On 20 March 2010 Portugal cleaned their country with 200,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.net/2010/03/20/massive-countryside-clean-up-in-portugal/ |title=Massive countryside clean-up in Portugal |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref> [[Let's Clean Slovenia in One Day!|Slovenia followed shortly]], breaking all records with 270,000 people (which is 13% of the overall population of the country) taking part in the action.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/video/?/video/international/2010/05/03/wv.clean.up.slovenia.cnn |title=CNN: Big clean up in Slovenia |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref> In the beginning of June the same year, Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine was cleaned.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> By the end of 2011 more than 2.5 million people have participated in Let’s Do It! cleanup actions in 16 countries – Estonia, India, Slovenia, Serbia, Finland, Romania, Latvia, Lithuania, Portugal, Bulgaria, Moldova, Ukraine, Cambodia, Russia, Hungary and Brazil.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.letsdoitworld.org/statistics |title=Let's Do It! World country statistics |date= |accessdate=2011-12-09}}</ref>
==World Cleanup 2012== In 2012, starting from 24 March until 25 September, a series of cleanups happened around the globe, on all continents, bringing together millions of volunteers in 96 countries.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> The action was initiated on 24 March 2012 by [[Let's Clean Slovenia|volunteers in Slovenia]] and [[Portugal]].
To bring together doers and initiators and share existing experience – Let's Do It! teams were organizing workshops and regional gatherings, introducing the World Cleanup 2012 around the world. Each group or organisation was leading the cleanup action in their country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.letsdoitworld.org/countries |title=Let's Do It! World countries |date= |accessdate=2011-12-09}}</ref>
<gallery> Cleanup in Armenia.jpg|[[Armenia]] Let's Do It! Bangladesh 2012.jpg|[[Bangladesh]] Slovenska vojska v okoljski akciji Očistimo Slovenijo 2012 (4).jpg|[[Slovenia]] </gallery> ==World Cleanup actions until 2018== After a successful World Cleanup 2012 project, the network set more ambitious goals. During the [https://web.archive.org/web/20140310071639/http://www.letsdoitworld.org/news/civic-leaders-40-countries-gather-kosovo-erase-massive-waste-problem Let's Do It! Clean World Conference held in Prishtina], Kosovo on the 6th-9th of February 2014, it was agreed, that the aim of the global movement is to clean up the whole World from illegally dumped solid waste and to then keep the planet clean. To reach the essential transformation in the global society, the leaders of country cleanups set the ambitious goal to involve 380 million people by 2018. According to Let's Do It! World, this is around 5% of the world’s population and is estimated to be the amount to create a lasting change.
==Biggest cleanup actions== [[File:Let's Do It! Ukraine 2015.jpg|thumb|Let's Do It! Ukraine 2015]] The most massive cleanup actions (data: October 2014) within the movement have happened in Slovenia, Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Kosovo and in Albania.
In 2012, 289,000 '''Slovenians''' came out of the homes and cleaned up the entire country in just one day. This is 14% of the country's population.
In 2013, 375,000 cleaned up the country in '''Bulgaria''' in a one-day country cleanup action (13,9% of country's population).
In 2012, 210,000 people (10% of country's population) cleaned up '''Latvia''' from illegal waste in just one day.
In 2013, a massive civic cleanup action also took place in '''Kosovo''', bringing together 132,000 people (7% of the population) and in the same year, Albania also had a massive cleanup action, uniting 147,000 people (5,25%) to clean up the country in just one day.
In 2015, 250,000 people (8,6% of country's population) cleaned up '''Lithuania''' from illegal waste in one day.
In 2015, over 500,000 people participated in Let's Do It! actions in '''Ukraine''' cleaning up illegal dump-sites around the country.
==World Cleanup 2018== {{Main|World Cleanup Day}}
Around 15 millions people in 158 countries took part on the World Clean Up Day, the 15th of September 2018.

The '''list of modern [[fan conventions]]''' for various genres of entertainment extends to the first conventions held in the 1930s.
Some fan historians claim that the 1936 Philadelphia Science Fiction Conference, a.k.a. [[Philcon]], was the first science fiction convention ever held. Others, such as [[Fred Patten]] and [[Rob Hansen]], make this claim for the January 1937 event in [[Leeds]], [[England]],<ref>Mike Glyer. [http://www.fiawol.org.uk/fanstuff/THEN%20Archive/1937conFirst.htm "THE FIRST EVER CONVENTION,"] ''The Story So Far'' (Worldcon, 1987).</ref> organized by the Leeds Science Fiction League, which was specifically organised as a conference, with a program and speakers. Out of this came the first incarnation of the [[British Science Fiction Association]].
While a few conventions were created in various parts of the world within the period between 1935-1960, the number of convention establishments increased slightly in the 1960s and then increased dramatically in the 1970s, with many of the largest conventions in the modern era being established during the latter decade. Impeti for further establishment of local fan conventions include:
* The return of superhero characters and franchises during the [[Silver Age of Comic Books]] (1956-1970) * science fiction adaptations for television serials (e.g., ''[[Star Trek]]'') in the 1960s-1970s * the growth of role-playing (in the 1970s and 1980s) as a genre of tabletop, live-action and eventually video/computer gaming, which not only inspired roleplay of favorite characters in full-body costumes but also inspired existing franchises to adapt their themes for said methods of gaming * the growth in home taping (starting with VHS in the late 1970s) of television broadcasts, including popular serials. * the growth of computerized communication, including the Internet and Internet-dependent applications in the 1980s and 1990s.

page.title: List of science and engineering blunders

revision.text:
This is a '''list of engineering blunders''', i.e., gross errors or mistakes resulting from grave lack of proper consideration, such as stupidity, confusion, carelessness, or culpable ignorance,<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/blunder Blunder], Dictionary.com. ''[[Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary]]'' (accessed: February 04, 2009).</ref> which resulted in notable incidents. <!-- Please list here only the incidents which are * notable * have a Wikipedia article or section * described as blunders in multiple valid sources --> *[[Fort Montgomery (Lake Champlain)]] was sometimes referred to as "Fort Blunder", because the first version of the U.S. fort was inadvertently built on the Canadian side of the border. * The [[NASA]] [[Mars Climate Orbiter]], launched in 1998, burned up in the Martian atmosphere. A mixup between metric and [[U.S. customary unit|US Standard]] measurements in the controlling software caused the spacecraft to miss its intended 140–150 km altitude above Mars during orbit insertion, instead entering the Martian atmosphere at about 57 km. * The NASA [[Genesis (spacecraft)|Genesis]] mission was an attempt to sample particles from the solar wind. It successfully collected a sample and returned to Earth. However at the last moment the landing parachute failed to open and the return capsule smashed into the ground at high speed, contaminating the samples. The parachute failure was traced to an [[Genesis (spacecraft)#Mishap_Investigation_Board_(MIB)|accelerometer installed backwards]]. * The Quebec bridge disaster. * [[Tacoma Narrows Bridge (1940)]] * [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill]] caused by a faulty blowout preventer.
==See also== *[[List of disasters]] for aircraft/rail/shipwreck disasters *[[Catastrophic failure#Structural_failure|Catastrophic failure]] Structural failures *[[Space accidents and incidents]] ==External links== *[https://archive.is/20140717230517/http://blunderingboffins.altervista.org/ Drunk photons and the myth of the electromagnetic vorticity]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} '''Maurice Gerald Flitcroft''' (23 November 1929 – 24 March 2007) was a British [[golf]]er and audacious [[hoax]]er.
Flitcroft became notorious after hitting a score of 121 in the qualifying competition for the [[1976 Open Championship]]—the highest score recorded at the [[Open Championship]]—and by a self-professed "professional golfer".<ref name=Phantom>{{cite book|last=Murray|first=Scott|last2=Farnarby|first2=Simon|title=The Phantom of the Open|year=2010|publisher=Yellow Jersey Press|isbn=978-0-224-08317-1}}</ref> Subsequently, he gained significant media attention, being referred to as "the world's worst golfer". Following the 1976 Open, the rules were changed to prevent Flitcroft from attempting to enter again. Undeterred, he regularly attempted to enter the Open and several other golf competitions, either under his own name or under pseudonyms such as Gene Paceky (as in paycheque), Gerald Hoppy, and James Beau Jolley.<ref name=Phantom /> Flitcroft was married to Jean (died 2002) by whom he had two sons—one of whom caddied for him.
He is the subject of a biography, ''The Phantom of the Open'', by Scott Murray and [[Simon Farnaby]], published by [[Yellow Jersey Press]] in July 2010.<ref name=Phantom />
In his obituary, [[The Daily Telegraph]] commented thus:
:Maurice Flitcroft ...was a [[Chain smoking|chain-smoking]] shipyard crane-operator from [[Barrow-in-Furness]] whose persistent attempts to [[Gate crashing|gatecrash]] the British Open golf championship produced a sense of humour failure among members of the golfing establishment.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1547158/Maurice-Flitcroft.html|title=Maurice Flitcroft|work=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref>
== Early life == Flitcroft was born in [[Manchester]] on 23 November 1929.<ref name="auto" />
== The 1976 Open Championship == According to his unpublished memoirs, Flitcroft took up the game after watching the [[1974 Piccadilly World Match Play Championship]].<ref name=murray>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2008/sep/19/golf.rydercup |title=Crazy golfer |last=Murray |first=Scott |date=19 September 2008 |website=[[theguardian.com]]|access-date=14 July 2018}}</ref> Flitcroft had golfing ambitions well above his ability and came to notoriety in 1976 when, posing as a professional golfer, he managed to obtain a place to play in the qualifying round of [[The Open Championship]]—despite his previous experience amounting only to some hacking around on playing fields near his home. Flitcroft recalled, "I was looking to find fame and fortune but only achieved one of the two". He was inspired to enter the tournament by Walter Danecki, a postal worker from [[Milwaukee]] who, after being barred from becoming a professional by the [[Professional Golfers' Association of America]], entered the [[1965 Open Championship]] after telling the R&A that he was a pro and set a two-round score of 221 during qualifying.<ref name=murray />
When he discovered, to his shock, that any amateurs entering competitions had to have an official [[Golf handicap|handicap]]—something he lacked—he simply declared himself to be a professional. It was in the same 1976 Open that a young new player, the 19-year-old [[Seve Ballesteros]] first came to the public's attention. Flitcroft prepared for the tournament by studying a golf instruction manual by [[Peter Alliss]] which was borrowed from his local library. He further studied from instructional articles by the 1966 [[PGA Championship]] winner [[Al Geiberger]], and honed his skills on a nearby beach.<ref name="auto"/>
His deception (and ineptitude) were uncovered when he managed to card a 49-[[Over par|over-par]] 121—the worst score in the tournament's history; some of the other professionals playing with him were so angry that they successfully demanded a refund of their entry fees. In addition the R&A gave him a lifetime ban from all their courses.<ref name=murray /> It seems that none of the professionals noticed that his gear comprised only a red [[Imitation leather|imitation-leather]] bag and half a set of [[Mail order|mail-order]] clubs. As a result of his abilities, he became known as "[[The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews|The Royal & Ancient]] Rabbit".
== Other work == After leaving school, Flitcroft joined the [[Merchant Navy (United Kingdom)|Merchant Navy]]. Following his marriage, he and his wife settled in Barrow-in-Furness, where he worked as a crane operator at the [[Vickers-Armstrongs]] shipyard.<ref name="auto"/> At other times he worked as a shoe polish salesman and an ice cream man.<ref name=chortle>{{cite web |url=https://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2017/02/24/26939/the_worlds_worst_golfer,_coming_to_cinemas# |title=The world's worst golfer, coming to cinemas |last=Richardson |first=Jay |date=24 February 2017 |website=[[Chortle]]|access-date=14 July 2018}}</ref>
In a July 2006 article in Golfonline, Flitcroft said, "I was in show business. I toured with a [[revue]], and I used to jump into a tank on the stage, I was a stuntcomedy [[high diver]]. The revue used to tour all the country and I would dive into this tank. It wasn't all glass, just the front so the spectators could see what was going on under the water."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.golfonline.com/golfonline/tours/britishopen/article/0,17742,1206885,00.html |title=Cloak and hacker |publisher=GolfOnline |first=Seth |last=Kelly |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060719210007/http://www.golfonline.com/golfonline/tours/britishopen/article/0%2C17742%2C1206885%2C00.html |archivedate=19 July 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
== After 1976 ==
After his initiation into celebrity golf, Flitcroft briefly became a C-list celebrity and had various golf trophies (usually those celebrating poor play or egregious mishaps) named after him; he also had the distinction of having the "Maurice Gerald Flitcroft Member-Guest Tournament" named after him by the 1988 Blythefield Country Club in [[Grand Rapids]]. Buddy Whitten, Blythefield's head pro stated that, "It started as a lark, but most people can't break 90 so they relate more to Maurice than they would to a touring pro." By the time of the 22nd Maurice G. Flitcroft Member-Guest Tournament, which was held in May 2000, the club had featured a [[Putting green|green]] with two [[Hole (golf)|holes]] so that even the most errant of approaches were potentially rewarded. If this wasn't enough another green had a {{Convert|12|in||adj=on}} cup.
In 1988, Flitcroft himself was flown to Blythefield to play in the event. He is reported as having told the members there that it was the first time he and his wife had been out of the house together "since their gas oven exploded." Whitten further said, "It was a different sort of experience, I'd never met a crane operator from England. But his game had gotten a little better than I expected. I think he shot in the low 90s." Flitcroft said of his performance, "I wasn't playing too well. Some faults had crept into my swing. But I hit a lot of good shots.”
Flitcroft retired from [[Vickers]] in the 1970s and devoted himself to his golf—but was reduced to the ignominy of once again playing on local fields, having been banned from every local golf club after sneaking into their grounds to play without permission.
Many years after his rise to fame, Flitcroft still received [[Mail|post]] which had been addressed simply to: Maurice Flitcroft, Golfer, England.
In 2017 comedian and writer Simon Farnaby, who co-wrote a biography of Flitcroft, stated that he was writing a film script based on the book.<ref name=chortle /> == References == {{reflist}}

A '''media monitoring service''', a '''press clipping service''' or a '''clipping service''' as known in earlier times, provides clients with copies of media content, which is of specific interest to them and subject to changing demand; what they provide may include documentation, content, analysis, or editorial opinion, specifically or widely. These services tend to specialize their coverage by subject, industry, size, geography, publication, journalist, or editor. The printed sources, which could be readily monitored, greatly expanded with the advent of [[telegraphy]] and [[submarine communication cable|submarine cables]] in the mid- to late-19th century; the various types of media now available proliferated in the 20th century, with the development of [[radio]], [[television]], the [[photocopier]] and the [[World Wide Web]]. Though media monitoring is generally used for capturing content or editorial opinion, it also may be used to capture advertising content.
Media monitoring services have been variously termed over time, as new players entered the market, new forms of media were created, and as new uses from available content developed. An existing group may provide such a monitoring service, as it relates to their main purpose, while a monitoring agency generally provides such as their main business. Alternative terms for these monitoring services as well as the information they provide include:
*Press clipping service or agency *Media cutting service or agency *[[Information logistics]] service *[[Media intelligence]] *Media information services
==History== {{See also|Imprimatur}} Since [[mass media]] traditionally was limited solely to print media, naturally the monitoring was also limited to these media. The world's first press clipping agency was established in [[London]] in 1852 by a Polish newsagent named Romeike. Actors, writers, musicians and artists would visit his shop to look for articles about themselves in his Continental stock. It was then that Romeike realised that he could turn this into a profitable business.
An agency named "L'Argus de la presse" was established in Paris in 1879 by Alfred Cherie, who offered a press-clipping service to Parisian actors, enabling them to buy reviews of their work rather than purchasing the whole newspaper.<ref>[http://mediamonitorsgroup.com/about-us/history Media Monitors Interactive history] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100430192851/http://mediamonitorsgroup.com/about-us/history |date=2010-04-30 }}</ref>
As [[radio]] and later [[television]] broadcasting were introduced in the 20th century, press clipping agencies began to expand their services into the monitoring of these broadcast media, and this task was greatly facilitated by the development of commercial audio and video tape recording systems in the 1950s and 1960s. With the growth of the [[Internet]] in the 1990s, media monitoring service extended their services to the monitoring of online information sources using new digital search and scan technologies to provide output of interest to their clients.
Then, in 1998, the now defunct WebClipping<ref>[http://www.webclipping.com WebClipping website]</ref> website was the first firm to start monitoring Internet based news media, moving the industry toward tracking digital news quickly.
Typically, individual or organisational clients – e. g. private companies and corporations, charities, government departments and ministries – will subscribe to a media monitoring service to keep track of what is being said about them, their field of operations, their competitors, or other specified topics of interest.
==Industry== The news monitoring industry provides government agencies, corporations, public relations professionals, and other organizations access to news information created by the media. Generally monitoring print, broadcast, and internet [[digital content|content]] for any mention of specific subjects of interest, a news monitoring company will analyze and provide feedback to their client in the form of press clippings, monitoring reports, and media analysis.
==Evolution==
From a cut & clip service, media clipping today has expanded to incorporate technology with information. Media monitoring clients can now opt to include print, broadcast and online to capture all their media exposure. While this technology has allowed some of the process to be automated, many media monitoring agencies still offer the services of trained professionals to review and validate results.
Service delivery happens at three fronts. Clients may get their original hard copy clips through traditional means (mail/overnight delivery) or may opt for digital delivery. Digital delivery allows the end user to receive via email all the relevant news of the company, competition and industry daily, with updates as they break. The same news may also be indexed (as allowed by copyright laws) in a searchable database to be accessed by subscribers. Another option of this service is auto-analysis, wherein the data can be viewed & compared in different formats.
Every organization that uses PR invariably uses news monitoring as well. In addition to tracking their own publicity, self-generated or otherwise, news monitoring clients also use the service to track competition or industry specific trends or legislation, to build a contact base of reporters, experts, leaders for future reference, to audit the effectiveness of their [[PR campaign]]s, to verify that PR, [[marketing]] and sales messages are in sync, and to measure impact on their target market. City, State, and Federal agencies use news monitoring services to stay informed in regions they otherwise would not be able to monitor themselves and to verify that the public information disseminated is accurate, accessible in multiple formats and available to the public. Some monitoring services specialize in one or more areas of press clipping, TV and radio monitoring, or [[internet tracking]]. Media analysis is also offered by most news monitoring services.
Television news monitoring companies, especially in the United States, capture and index [[closed captioning]] text and search it for client references. Some TV monitoring companies employ human monitors who review and abstract program content; other services rely on automated search programs to search and index stories.
Online media monitoring services utilize automated software called [[web spider|spiders]] or robots (bots) to automatically monitor the content of free online news sources including newspapers, magazines, trade journals, TV station and news syndication services. Online services generally provide links but may also provide text versions of the articles. Results may or may not be verified for accuracy by the online monitoring service. Most newspapers do not include all of their print content online and some have web content that does not appear in print.
In the United States, there are trade associations formed to share best practices which include the North American Conference of Press Clipping Services and the International Association of Broadcast Monitors.
==Language and media – the big challenges==
In English speaking countries, the service of media monitoring, [[collation]] & [[dissemination]] is fairly simple and most organizations which use [[Public Relations]] also use media monitoring. However, in multi-language & multi-dialect countries the challenge of collating data locally and disseminating in a [[language translation|translated]] language of business (usually English) is a daunting task. The situation in other multi-language countries is no different.
The second large challenge for Information Logistics is the growing number of media and the media types. For example, in a country like [[media in India|India]] there are over 50,000 registered print publications, 250+ TV channels, a growing number of relevant internet sites and several hundred new blogs that need to be captured every day. Several of these need to be translated for a 'heads-up' and analysis needs to be constant and real-time.
===Illustrative examples=== An author that recently published a book and who has a strong interest in tracking how well the book is received by [[critic]]s may hire a media monitoring service. The service will have a method by which they extract any information about the author and their book from newly printed [[magazine]]s, radio programs, television programs and so on. The author will receive a printed bundle of ''clippings'', i.e., the pages of the magazines and [[newspaper]]s relating to them and their book. They may also receive recordings of any radio reviews, television programs and so on, which refer to his book.
Most major companies and corporations subscribe to media monitoring services to keep track of any reports or comments in the media. A fast food company, for example, would receive summaries of coverage and/or copies of material drawn from a wide range of sources, including TV and radio news reports, commentaries on TV and radio shows, newspaper opinion/commentary columns, magazine articles and internet [[blog]]s.
The material collected would include any media items that relate to the company's commercial operations, its corporate [[reputation management|reputation]] or its media image. This would include reports about or discussions of the [[fast food industry]] in general, and any media item that specifically mentions the company, its clients and suppliers, its competitors or related interest groups or other specified subjects of interest, such as food/health regulations.
===Trade groups=== The [[International Association of Broadcast Monitors]] (IABM) is a worldwide [[trade association]] made up of news retrieval services which record, monitor and archive broadcast news sources including television, radio and internet. It acts as a "clearinghouse" or "forum" for discussion on topics of collective concerns and acts as a united voice for the news monitoring industry.
===Professional organization=== [[FIBEP]] (Federation Internationale des Bureaux d’Extraits de Presse/International Federation of the Press Clipping Services) is a professional media monitoring organization. The FIBEP was established in 1953 in [[Paris]] and has close to 100 members from 44 countries. Every 18 months, the members of FIBEP members organize a three-day FIBEP-Congress. In work groups, workshops, reports and discussion circles, members discuss market trends.
==Law cases== {{main|Associated Press v. Meltwater|Public Relations Consultants Association (PRCA) v The Newspaper Licensing Agency (NLA)}} Two parallel cases developed in 2012, [[Associated Press v. Meltwater|one in the United States]], and [[Public Relations Consultants Association (PRCA) v The Newspaper Licensing Agency (NLA)|one in the United Kingdom]]. In each case, the legality of temporary copies and the online media monitoring service offered to clients, was in dispute. Essentially the two cases covered the same issue (media clippings shown to clients online) and with the same defendant, [[Meltwater Group]]. The plaintiff differed, being [[List of copyright collection societies|a UK copyright collection society]] (UK) rather than [[Associated Press]] (US), but upon parallel grounds.
The activity was ruled unlawful in the US (under the "[[fair use]]" doctrine) and lawful in the UK (under UK and EU copyright law, in summary on the basis that mere viewing is never an infringement, and temporary copies to enable a lawful purpose are themselves lawful).

[[Princeton University]]
[[American Museum of Natural History]] |alma_mater = {{nowrap|[[Harvard College]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[University of Texas at Austin]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]])
[[Columbia University]] ([[Master of Philosophy|MPhil]], [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]])}} |thesis_title = A study of the abundance distributions along the minor axis of the Galactic bulge |thesis_url = http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1992PhDT.........1T |thesis_year = 1991 |doctoral_advisor = R. Michael Rich |known_for = |influences = {{flatlist| * [[Isaac Newton]] * [[Carl Sagan]] * [[Richard Feynman]] * [[Albert Einstein]]}} |influenced = |prizes = [[NASA Distinguished Public Service Medal]] (2004)
